content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A scientist wants to design two circuits consisting of wires, a switch, a battery with internal resistance, a light bulb, and an uncharged capacitor. In Circuit 1, the bulb will gradually increase in brightness when the switch is closed, becoming brightest after the switch has been closed for a long time. In Circuit 2, the bulb will be brightest when the switch is closed, decreasing in brightness with time, and going out completely when the switch has been closed for a long time.

i. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. Determine an expression for the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R comma f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> in the resistor after the switch has been closed for a very long time.

(d) The scientist modifies the circuit from part (b) by adding a second identical resistor in series with the other circuit components. Indicate how the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R comma lowercase i, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> in the resistor immediately after the switch is closed compares to that in the circuit from part (b).
